That's great to hear! Improving your Japanese language skills will definitely make a huge difference in your dining experiences in Tokyo. Being able to communicate with chefs and read menus will open up more options for you and allow you to try new things.

Here are some useful phrases you might find helpful when dining out:

* "" (Vegetarian ryori arimasu ka?) - "Do you have vegetarian dishes?"
* "" (Bejitarian menyu arimasu ka?) - "Do you have a vegetarian menu?"
* "" (Kono ryori wa bejitarian desu ka?) - "Is this dish vegetarian?"
* "" (Niku to sakana wa arimasen ka?) - "Does this dish contain meat or fish?"
* "" (O-namae wa nan desu ka?) - "What is the name of this dish?" (helpful for asking about ingredients)

Some other tips:

* Many restaurants have picture menus or displays, which can be helpful if you're not sure what something is.
* Don't be afraid to ask your server or the chef about ingredients or preparation methods. They're usually happy to help.
* Consider carrying a small phrasebook or using a translation app on your phone to help with more complex questions.
* If you have a food allergy or intolerance, it's a good idea to learn the Japanese words for common allergens like peanuts (), gluten (), and dairy ().

Keep up the good work with your Japanese language studies, and I'm sure you'll become a pro at navigating Tokyo's food scene in no time!
